Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General
Notes: Source document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request to the agency.

Description: Fifty-five hospitals in 21 states agreed to pay the United States a total of more than $34 million to settle allegations that they submitted false claims to Medicare for kyphoplasty, a minimally-invasive procedure used to treat certain spinal fractures that often are due to osteoporosis.

Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General
Notes: Source document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request to the agency.

Description: Detroit Medical Center, a non-profit company that owns and operates hospitals and outpatient facilities in Detroit, agreed to pay the United States $30 million to settle allegations that it violated the False Claims Act, the Anti-Kickback Statute and the Stark Statute, by engaging in improper financial relationships with referring physician.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Company: Fountain Valley Regional Hospital and Medical Center
Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General
Notes: Source document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request to the agency.

Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Description: Tenet Healthcare Corporation subsidiary Lifemark Hospitals of Florida paid the United States $29 million to settle allegations that Lifemark, Tenet and various affiliated and predecessor companies violated the False Claims Act in connection with submitted to the Medicare Program.

Primary Offense: Medicare Parts C and D Enforcement Action
Description: improper contract administration

Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General
Notes: Source document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request to the agency.

Description: The Department of Justice reached 70 settlements involving 457 hospitals in 43 states for more than $250 million related to cardiac devices that were implanted in Medicare patients in violation of Medicare coverage requirements.

Tenet HealthCare paid the United States $4.3 million to settle allegations that five of its Florida hospitals violated the False Claims Act through upcoding. The five hospitals were Coral Gables Hospital, Parkway Regional Medical Center in North Miami Beach, Hollywood Medical Center, Hialeah Hospital and Florida Medical Center in Fort Lauderdale.
Tenet Healthcare Corporation, operator of a large hospital chain, agreed to pay the United States $900 million for alleged unlawful billing practices.

A major U.S. hospital chain, Tenet Healthcare Corporation, and two of its Atlanta-area subsidiaries agreed to pay over $513 million to resolve criminal charges and civil claims relating to a scheme to defraud the United States and to pay kickbacks in exchange for patient referrals. Tenet HealthSystem Medical Inc. and its subsidiaries entered into a non-prosecution agreement while two other Tenet subsidiaries, Atlanta Medical Center Inc. and North Fulton Medical Center Inc., agreed to plead guilty to conspiracy to defraud the United States and to pay health care kickbacks and bribes in violation of the Anti-Kickback Statute.
Tenet Healthcare Corporation agreed to pay the United States $42.75 million to settle allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by overbilling the federal Medicare program.

Tenet Healthcare Corporation agreed to pay the United States $22.5 million to resolve allegations that one of its facilities improperly billed Medicare for millions of dollars for referrals provided by doctors with whom the hospital had prohibited financial arrangements.

One hundred thirty-nine hospitals currently or formerly operated by Tenet Healthcare Corporation agreed to pay the United States and 22 states $17 million to settle allegations that the facilities overcharged federal health care programs in connection with laboratory services.

Tenet Healthcare Corporation agreed to pay $10 million to settle allegations that it failed to disclose to investors that its strong earnings growth from 1999 to 2002 was driven largely by its exploitation of a loophole in the Medicare reimbursement system.

Primary Offense: Medicare Parts C and D Enforcement Action
Description: improper contract administration

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Western District of New York

Info Source: Contained in data obtained on August 17, 2017 in response to an open records request.

Private Litigation Case Title: Cason-Merendo et al v. VHS of Michigan, Inc. et al
Notes: This case, which was brought as an antitrust action, accused various Detroit-area hospitals of conspiring to depress the wages of nurses.

Description: meal/rest break violation
Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of Orange
Notes: The settlement (worth up to $85 million) also covered two other state actions and one federal action, details of which are given at https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/70318/000119312509035651/d10k.htm#toc58854_6. See also https://www.ocregister.com/2009/03/11/oc-hospital-owner-to-pay-85m-to-settle-ot-dispute/

Company: Tenet Healthcare Corporation d/b/a Saint Vincent Hospital

Description: More than 100 hospitals currently or formerly operated by Tenet Healthcare Corporation agreed to pay $820,000 to settle multistate litigation alleging they overcharged government health care programs in connection with laboratory services. This was part of a larger $17 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-tenet-healthcare-corporation-3

Tenet Healthcare agreed to pay a total of $123 million to Georgia and South Carolina to setttle litigation alleging that two of its facilities paid illegal kickbacks in exchange for patient referrals. This was part of a larger $513 million civil and criminal settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-tenet-healthcare-corporation-5

Tenet Healthcare Corporation agreed to pay $400,000 as part of the settlement of litigation stemming from its attempt to close the Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital in violation of public-interest conditions imposed on Tenet's purchase of the nonprofit facility.

Info Source: Attorney General Charlie Crist Announces $7 Million in Tenet Settlement, US States News, February 21, 2006 (via Nexis).
INFORMATION ISSUED BY U.S. ATTORNEY'S OFFICE FOR THE SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA ON MAY 17, US Fed News, May 17, 2006 (via Nexis).

Description: Tenet Healthcare Corporation and its affiliated hospital Desert Regional Medical Center (DRMC), a general medical and surgical hospital located in Palm Springs, California, agreed to pay $1.41 million to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by knowingly charging Medicare for implanting unnecessary cardiac monitors.
